dataIdInfo.idPurp: Planning and analysis. Feed information to Trapeze, Clever, ATIS, Orbital, Cubic (Farebox), Next Bus, WMATA Website, and Metroview (ArcGIS Server Flex Web applications).
dataIdInfo.idAbs: This dataset represents Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority (WMATA) bus routes. It includes regular and pattern routes. All WMATA GIS data is stored and exported in WMATA LDP NAD 1983 [NSRS2007] US Feet.

placeKeys.keyword: Arlington County, City of Alexandria, City of Fairfax, City of Falls Church, District of Columbia, Fairfax County, Loudoun County, Montgomery County, Prince George's County, Prince William County, Washington DC, Washington DC Metropolitan Area, WMATA Service Area

themeKeys.keyword: Transit, METRO, WMATA, Bus, Transit Operation, Planning, MetroAccess, Paratransit

Consts.useLimit: WMATA GIS data has been created from records and information compiled by various WMATA offices at different times and at different map scales. Every reasonable effort has been made to ensure the accuracy and completeness of the data. However, WMATA makes no representations, warranties, or guarantees of the accuracy or completeness of this data, nor of its fitness for any particular purpose. Data created by WMATA may not be copyrighted by any other party.

dataIdInfo.envirDesc: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.2.2.3574

report.measDesc: The Bus Routes and Bus Patterns feature class contains all routes and patterns as defined by BPLN and BOSC as of the date of the last service change. Service changes happen quarterly and all bus-related GIS feature classes are current as of last effective date. All attributes contained within the feature class were decided upon by WMATA stakeholders and deemed of significant enough business value to warrant inclusion in the dataset.

Routes are constructed from NavTEQ street segments supplemented with digitized segments for areas (from Bing imagery, but if not then site construction drawings (if available) and/or other data from DDOT, VDOT, MDOT) that NavTEQ does not have data. After all segments underlying the route are selected and attributed with the [ROUTEKEY] a topology check is performed to ensure there are no gaps or dangles. All segments are then merged and the resultant polyline is flipped to show the correct direction of travel. Manual checks are done to ensure that all road segments properly intersect (i.e. underpasses do not connect to overpasses).

The horizontal accuracy of the feature class is identical to that of the source data, NavTEQ Streets.
From NavTEQ: Roads and ferries cannot share geometry with railways, runways, country boundaries, or any water links. Additionally, Building/Landmark polygons which require sufficient detail to make the building recognizable, can never share geometry with navigable links. All other cartography may share geometry based on the generalization rules. For example, a road link or railroad link may also have a feature of state park or hospital. Cartography and administrative boundary features in Detailed City areas can be generalized up to 25 meters/82 feet (except built-up areas) and 100 meters/328 feet for built-up areas Cartography and administrative boundary features in Inter-Town areas can be generalized up to 250 meters/820 feet (except built-up areas) 100 meters/328 feet for built-up areas.

The routes and patterns contained within the feature class are current as of the effective date of the last signup period. No date field is maintained within the feature class. However, each signup is issued a unique number that can be used to trace its origin in time.

Every Regular (R) and Pattern (P) feature in the dataset was assigned the following attribute values based on input from WMATA’s Office of Bus Planning (BPLN) and Office of Bus Scheduling (BOSC) either from personal communication or published documents:
[RT_D], [ROUTE], [DIRECTION], [ORIGIN], [DESTINATION], [DESCRIPTION], [REGIONAL], [EXPRESS], [M-F_SERVICE], [SAT_SERVICE], [SUN_SERVICE], [SCHOOL_SERVICE], [LINE], [SERVICE_TYPE], [ROUTEKEY]
[OBJECTID], [Shape], [SHAPE_LEN], [TYPE] are all GIS constructs.
As primary stakeholders in bus-related data, BOSC and BPLN have final say as to attribute accuracy and all input is treated as such.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.
Coordinates defining the features.

attr.attrdef:
Concatenation of ROUTE and DIRECTION for the pattern.
E.G. - J4_E equates to Route J4 Eastbound.

attrdomv.udom:
Concatenation of ROUTE and DIRECTION for the pattern.
E.G. - J4_E equates to Route J4 Eastbound.
Metrobus Route in which the pattern is contained

attr.attrdef: Travel direction of the pattern, as assigned by BPLN/BOSC

attrdomv.udom: Travel Direction Values.

edom.edomvds: BPLN Revenue Route Description of route, BOSC Clever Analyst DB (RouteVars table)
BPLN Revenue Route Description of route, BOSC Clever Analyst DB (RouteVars table)
BPLN Revenue Route Description of route, BOSC Clever Analyst DB (RouteVars table)
BPLN Revenue Route Description of route, BOSC Clever Analyst DB (RouteVars table)

edom.edomvd: Loop Route (Start and End at same point)
edom.edomvds: BPLN Revenue Route Description of route, BOSC Clever Analyst DB (RouteVars table)

attrdomv.udom: Value is determined by the hierarchy assigned within the Trapeze Route Variations table (BOSC)

edom.edomvd: Regular route. Assigned to the regular pattern the bus takes within the route (per direction). Corresponds with a non-variation (regular) pattern in trapeze.
Alternate pattern, corresponds with a variation pattern in Trapeze

attr.attrdef: Landmark/area of where the pattern begins

attrdomv.udom:
Landmark/area of where the pattern begins. Value can be the following:
1. Bus Stop (On and At Streets) 2. Transit Center (e.g. - Pentagon) 3. Nearby Landmark (e.g. - Leisure World)

attr.attrdef: Landmark/area of where the pattern ends.

attrdomv.udom:
Landmark/area of where the pattern ends. Value can be the following:
1. Bus Stop (On and At Streets) 2. Transit Center (e.g. - Pentagon) 3. Nearby Landmark (e.g. - Leisure World)
Text description of the line in which the pattern falls within.

attr.attrdef: WMATA enterprise GIS identifier. Provides link to Oracle DocLink tables (for schedules in MetroView)

attrdomv.udom: Unique geographic feature identifier assigned within the WMATA enterprise GIS
State abbreviations
Regional bus route designation

attr.attrdef: Largest division of bus routing, which contains multiple routes. Used in Trapeze.

attrdomv.udom: Numerical ID of the line in which the pattern falls within.

attr.attrdef: Type of service provided by the pattern

edom.edomvd: Bus route designed to connect outlying areas to each other, or enable transfer connections between routes, but does not enter the Central Business District (i.e. downtown)
Bus route designed to connect the outlying areas to the Central Business District (i.e. downtown)

attrdomv.udom: Bus service type

attr.attrdef: Defines whether the pattern runs as an express route

attrdomv.udom: Express bus route designation

attr.attrdef: Defines if the pattern is in service on Monday through Friday.

attrdomv.udom: Weekday bus route designation
Saturday bus route designation

attr.attrdef: Defines if the pattern is in service on Sunday

attrdomv.udom: Sunday bus route designation

Defines if the pattern runs as a school route.
Domain set to either "Y" or "N"
Date in which the feature was created. Automatically populated when feature is created.
Date in which feature was edited. Automatically populated when feature is created.

Effective Start Date of the pattern
Defined as the day of the service change, or latest push to SDE. All start dates must have a time of 03:00:00 AM

Effective End Date of the Pattern
Defined by the service change, or the next push to SDE. If the pattern is current, it will have an assumed end date of 9/9/9999. All end dates must have a time of 02:59:00 AM.
Source Memorandum of the pattern. Values include BPLN/BOSC staff correspondence/direction listed as a source.
Retrieved from BOSC RouteVars table (Clever Analyst DB). ID is unique when querying all current operating patterns.

The Bus Planning Office has historically used Alpha- Numeric or Numeric designations or symbols for bus routes both within the office in various schedule documents, for the published timetables as well as for the electronic bus destination signs. However, in order to identify bus routes in the Cubic/GFI fare collection database, the interface between the GPS system and the Farebox requires that the routes be numerically coded and limited to a string of 5 characters.
A bus Line is composed of a either a single bus route or multiple bus routes that share a common street segment or trunk with varied branches and terminal points

Defines if the routes operate Saturday supplement schedule.
On Federal Government Workforce Holidays – Columbus Day, Veterans Days, MLK Day and President’s Day, only 4 days a year, WMATA run an adjusted level of bus service which is less than a regular weekday but more than a regular Satuday Schedule

WMATA parsed its local jurisdictions into quadrants, zones or sectors using natural or roadway boundaries. The intent was to evaluate service demand and performance for a neighborhood, or specific geographic area with respect to the subset of routes serving the area. The population density the street network and/or other physical or socio-economic characteristics may help define the boundaries that were established.
Bus planning sector name or description.

The Corridor can be a sub-jurisdictional or inter-jurisdiction designation for a service area that aligns along one or more major arterials and or parallel roadways which are serviced by one or bus routes or bus lines. Corridors are typically more elongated or extended than service sectors. The street network and the bus route alignment nearly exclusively define the boundaries. Each Corridor has an ID number. Each Corridor has an ID number.
Corridor description
A corridor can encompass one or more Bus Lines or Bus Routes.

Each Bus Line operates at various levels of service, defined in terms of service days scheduled, daily starting and ending times (or hourly span of daily service), average trip frequency and average ridership per day, per hour, per trip. The Service Plan designation indicates that the average daily ridership of a given bus line falls within a certain range that is common among other lines sharing the same Service Plan.
Revenue service type
Operational Status

edom.edomvd: Seasonally or Temporarily Scheduled and Operational

attrdomv.udom: Notes about service or schedule changes fare changes
